posts.name: Joshua Epperson
posts.cooked: I’m using pathplanners ramsete differential drive autobuilder and I noticed my robot was acting funky during paths. When I commanded it to curve to the right it would go to the left. This made me think that perhaps the wheel speeds are inverted so I inverted my PID output such that the left side’s voltage is based on the right side’s PID and the right side’s voltage is based on the left side’s PID. This is quite hacky and it leads to my pp_ramseterotation error to always being around 180 degrees/2pi radians when I reach the end of my path. Although what I did seems to work I want to know how I can properly fix this.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
I have a few questions of the, "Is it plugged in, and did you try rebooting?’ variety to help provide a baseline.

Could the encoders (or one of them) be inverted?

Did you try using Sysid to tune the constants first?

posts.name: KaseyB
posts.cooked:
We fought with this last year and it turned out that the students didn’t properly assign the CAN IDs of the left/right side of the robot. They fixed it in teleop by reversing the turn direction so it wasn’t noticed for a while.

I would suggest creating a teleop drive command and see if the robot goes the direction you think it should be going.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
Some simple things to check:

Are all of your CAN ids right?

Make a simple auto that just calls DrivetrainSubsystem.tankDriveVolts for a few seconds.  Does a positive voltage make the robot move forwards?  Try one positive and one negative.  Does it turn in the right direction?

Call getWheelSpeeds in DrivetrainSubsystem.periodic and log the results to SmartDashboard .  Are the numbers positive when the robot is moving forwards?

Check that the odometry also goes in the right direction.  You can use your Field2d to do this.

posts.name: edf42001
posts.cooked: Along with these excellent ideas, try checking which alliance is set on the driverstation. Path planner automatically by default adjusts paths on the blue alliance to the red alliance to compensate for the non-rotationally-symmetric field. This could be causing the left/right turning difference. Try setting the driverstation to the blue alliance.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
bovlb:

You can use your Field2d to do this

This is an excellent idea. You could actually plot the feild2d in the simulator as another sanity check. That may show a difference between what the robot sees and real world results.
Really unlikely but it happened to us one year if one of your motors is wired backwards on the actual bot that could be the cause of the issue.
